chapter.title: Welcome to the iDART Pharmacy Tool
chapter.simpara: iDART (which stands for the Intelligent Dispensing of Antiretroviral Treatment) is a tool designed to help pharmacists and pharmacy assistants with the monthly dispensing of antiretroviral drugs. iDART is designed in the context of a resource constrained environment, the public health sector in South Africa. iDART seeks to address many of the problems typical of this type of environment. The development of iDART was the result of collaboration work between Cell-Life and the Desmond Tutu HIV Centre, in Cape Town, South Africa. iDART is an open source project and the source code can be downloaded from http://idart.Cell-Life.org. It is released under GPL, so please feel free to distribute this program under its license agreement. Any thoughts or comments would be greatly appreciated. Please send these to idart@cell-life.org.za.

sect1.simpara: The Cell-Life Helpdesk is available between 9am and 5pm, Monday to Friday. If you have a problem with the system that you cannot solve using the documentation provided, please feel free to call us. iDART is a chaptericipatory design project. If this isn't possible, have a pen and paper ready. The helpdesk can be reached by:

chapter.title: Features of the iDART Pharmacy Tool
chapter.simpara: iDART was developed in conjunction with the Desmond Tutu HIV Centre as a result of a doctorâ€™s requests for a solution to help manage and monitor ARV stock control and patient therapy dispensing. The challenges identified by the doctor which Cell-Life has addressed included:

listitem.simpara: A need to monitor ARV stock levels at any given time
A need to be alerted whenever a specific drug level was low
A need to be notified when any drugs were about to expire
A need to be notified when patients defaulted on treatment collection
A need to have an electronic patient history
A need to help manage large numbers of patient numbers on ART simply and effectively
A need to monitor a patients packaging, dispensing and monitoring of drugs
A need to reduce costs associated with dispensing
A need to save time in the process of report creation

sect1.title: Key benefits of the iDART system:

listitem.simpara: Accurate tracking of patient treatment
Comprehensive patient history to treatment
Accurate ARV stock control management
Time saving of pharmacy dispensing through faster processing
Reduces and identifies loss of ARVs
Operates through clearly identifiable, multi-lingual bar-coded labels which are created for each and every drug and patient package

sect1.title: The Technology
sect1.simpara: iDART is developed using open-source technologies and has been developed to run on any windows or linux based platform, allowing users to access and operate the system in a familiar and easy to use way. The choice for using open-source software is that there are no proprietary licensing costs associated with the use of the software. The use of open-source also allows for people to take the software for free and use it at their sites should they have the necessary skills to manage its operation. Each iDART installation operates with a barcode label printer connected to the PC which allows for each and every drug which is packaged to be clearly labelled. The labels which are printed upon dispensing can also be created in a range of languages depending on the ART site. The labels make for easy drug information and label packaging and eradicate many of the errors that occur through handwritten dosage instructions.

sect1.title: The Reporting Tool
sect1.simpara: One of the more important functions of iDART is in the various reports that the software makes available. The reports range from basic stock control management and monitoring reports to specific patient defaulter lists which allow for the easy management and follow-up of patients. iDART also keeps the entire patient history of a patient in its database and allows for accurate tracking of patients receiving treatment from ART sites. It is important to note that Cell-Life believe strongly in addressing the needs of each specific site and the technology used is flexible enough to include numerous other reports. Cell-Life believe that the technology implemented needs to assist the existing processes in place at sites and therefore looks to adapt the technology to best suit these needs.

sect1.title: Down Referral or Decanting to remote clinics
sect1.simpara: One of the great features of iDART is that it also allows for the decanting of packages to remote clinics and dispensaries that do not hold stock of ARVs. iDART allows a central ART site or pharmacy to prepare packages for a patients belonging to remote clinics and will trace the entire process until the patient collects their drugs. Feedback is then provided via the network to the central pharmacy to signal that the package was collected and the pharmacist is then allowed to package drugs for the patient in the next month. For more information on the decanting system please see the Cell-Life website. If you have any further queries on iDART please visit our website at www.Cell-Life.org or call 021 469 1111.

chapter.title: System Overview
chapter.simpara: This section provides a short description of the function of iDART, and shows how the tool can be used in a pharmacy that dispenses antiretroviral drugs.

iDart allows ARVs to be pre-packaged for collection by patients at a later time. The packaged drugs may either be collected at the pharmacy or at a remote clinic. iDART also allows users to dispense ARVs immediately to patients at a pharmacy.

sect1.title: Pre-packaging ARVs for patients
sect1.simpara: For quick dispensing, iDART allows the pharmacist to pre-package a patient's ARVs. The patient may then collect their pre-packaged ARVs at the pharmacy or at a remote clinic. The date on which the ARVs were pre-packaged is recorded by iDART to assist with the tracking of the packages.

sect2.title: Collection at the pharmacy
sect2.simpara: If the patient collects the packaged ARVs at the pharmacy, the date on which the package is collected as well as the date on which the package leaves the pharmacy are recorded as the current day.

sect2.title: Collection at the local clinic
sect2.simpara: Before a patient can collect the packaged ARVs at the local clinic, the packaged ARVs need to be transported from the pharmacy to the remote/local clinic. The date on which the packaged ARVs leave the pharmacy is recorded. The packaged drugs are then transported to the clinic. The clinic eventually receives the packaged ARVs and this date is recorded. Finally, when the patient arrives to collect his/her packaged ARVs, the date for collection is recorded.

sect1.title: Dispensing to patients at the pharmacy immediately
sect1.simpara: If a patient arrives at the pharmacy to collect his/her ARVs and the ARVs have not been pre-packaged, iDART allows the pharmacist to package and dispense the required ARVs immediately. In this case, the date the package was packed, the date the package left the pharmacy and the date the package was picked up will all be recorded as the same day.

sect1.title: Remote Dispensing Feature
sect1.simpara: This section provides a more detailed description of the remote dispensing feature in iDART.

Generally, ART consists of a monthly supply of 3 different types of drugs. These 3 drugs need to be taken together. While it is customary for a pharmacist to dispense directly to a patient, iDART allows for pharmacist to create packages for each individual under their responsibility, at a central pharmacy. Labels are printed for each of the 3 drugs in the package, and each label has a reference to the individual patient. The pharmacist can then use a courier service to distribute the months supply to a remote rural or semi-rural clinic. It is at this clinic that the patient visits on a monthly basis to pick up their medications. In addition to the remote packaging of ARVs, iDART also allows for the direct dispensing of ARVs to a patient. Since there are two separate locations in the physical infrastructure, iDART consists of two separate applications. The first of these resides at the central pharmacy. The second application is housed at a service point or ARV site, where patients collect their medication from a nurse. Since both applications access the same database, the responsible pharmacist can assess each site that receives drugs from the central store, as well as assess all patients monitored on the system.

Since the drugs are couriered to remote areas, it is very important for the responsible pharmacist to know the location of drugs at all stages of the distribution. For this reason, the packages are tracked at 4 specific times along the supply chain. Tracking normally happens by using a handheld barcode scanner. The first time we store information about the packaged drugs is when the package is first created. In other words, the time when the pharmacist has placed the 3 different drugs into a plastic package is recorded. The second time the package is tracked is when it leaves the pharmacy. The pharmacist scans out the package. When this happens, we know that the drugs are now in transit to the destined remote clinic. The third time the package is tracked is when it arrives at the remote clinic. The nurse working at this facility is responsible for receiving the packaged drugs from the driver, and scanning in the packages as a receipt of their arrival. The final time the package is tracked is when the patient visits the remote clinic to pick up their monthly supply of ARV. The package is then scanned out. By scanning this out, a feedback mechanism is created. In other words, the pharmacist can obtain the location and status of the packages between dispensing and patient pickup.

chapter.title: Getting Started: Updating Pharmacy Details And Adding Drugs, Stock, Doctors, Patients and their Prescriptions
chapter.simpara: The Basic Concepts section describes tasks you will need to perform to set up the system for your pharmacy. First, the pharmacy's details (such as address, telephone number etc) must be entered. Then, the ARV drugs that will be dispensed to patients (such as Efavirenz 200mg Capsules, Kaletra Solution etc) must be added. Once the drugs have been added, the stock levels for each drug must be recorded. If you would like iDART to store regimen information, you will also need to define the groups of ARV drugs that can be prescribed as regimen 1A, 1B or 2.
Patients must be added next, followed by the doctors who will prescribe drugs to the patients. Existing prescriptions for the patients must then be recorded.

chapter.title: The Pharmacy
chapter.simpara: The system stores the pharmacy's name, address and phone number as well as the name of the pharmacist in charge. This information is printed on package and drug labels. In addition, the names of the pharmacist and pharmacy assistant are printed on all iDART reports.

sect1.title: Updating the Pharmacy's Details
sect1.simpara: To update the pharmacy's information, log into the system and select General Admin from the main screen. A new screen, the General Admin Screen, will appear. From this screen, select Update the Pharmacy's Details in the Pharmacy Admin section. The Pharmacy Info screen will appear. It looks like this:

To change any of the details, click in the text box, and edit or delete the existing text. The label preview will change to reflect your changes. The name of the Head Pharmacist will appear on all labels, and on all reports. The name of the Pharmacy Assistant, if set, will appear on all reports. When you are finished, click Save . To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving any of your changes, press Cancel .

chapter.title: ARV Drugs
chapter.simpara: The system stores all the ARV drugs that will be given to patients. The drug is referenced by its name, which should therefore include the abbreviation and strength. For example, you might have [d4t] Stavudine 30mg. You need to specify the chemical compounds in the drug, fill in the pack size, and select the form (tablets, solution etc) as this determines the dosage instructions that will be printed on the drug label. You can optionally specify a standard dosage for the drug. Before the existing stock of a drug can be recorded, it must be added as shown in this section. If you are unsure about drug attributes, try looking at the example with fields filled in, found in the Adding Drugs section.

sect1.title: Adding Drugs
sect1.simpara: Drugs are added using the Add Drug screen. To add a drug, log into the system and select General Admin from the main screen. A new screen, the General Admin Screen , will appear. From this screen, select Add a new Drug . The Add a New Drug screen will appear. It looks like this:

To start, fill in the drug name in the Drug Name field. This should include the drug's abbreviation (for ARV drugs), full name and strength. An example is [d4t] Stavudine 30mg. Note that duplicate drug names are not allowed in iDART Next, fill in the drug's chemical composition. Select one or more chemical compounds from the table on the right hand side, and fill in their strength (in mg or mg/ml) by clicking in the strength column and entering the value. If the chemical compound you want to select is not in the list, you will need to add it to the database using the Add Chemical Compound button. Please be aware that this should only be done if you are absolutely sure you want to add the chemical compound. You will be asked to enter you password to confirm. Now, fill in the other fields, making sure you fill in all fields marked with * as these are compulsory. Standard dosage is not compulsory, but if you do fill in a standard dosage for a drug you can always change this for individual prescriptions. Here is an example with all the fields filled in:
When you are finished, click Save to add the drug. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the drug, press Cancel .

sect1.title: Updating a Drug's Information
sect1.simpara:
Drugs are updated using the Update an Existing Drug screen. To update a drug, select General Admin from the main screen. A new screen, the General Admin Screen, will appear. From this screen, select
Update an Existing Drug's Information
. The Update an Existing Drug screen will appear. It looks like this:

To get the drug's current information, you should use the drug search. For more information about using the drug search, please see Using the Drug Search. Once the information for an existing drug is displayed, you can edit this information. Ensure that at least the fields marked with * are filled. All other fields are optional, but recommended. The text in the Drug Name field will be printed on the drug label during dispensing, so be sure to include the strength, form and quantity, as is shown in the example above. An example is [d4t] Stavudine 30mg. Note that duplicate drug names are not allowed in iDART. You should also make sure the drug's chemical composition is correct. To change the chemical composition, select one or more chemical compounds from the table on the right hand side, and fill in their strength (in mg or mg/ml) by clicking in the strength column and entering the value. If the chemical compound you want to select is not in the list, you will need to add it to the database using the Add Chemical Compound button. Please be aware that this should only be done if you are absolutely sure you want to add the chemical compound. You will be asked to enter you password to confirm.
When you are finished, click Save to change the drug's information. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without changing the drug information, press Cancel .

chapter.title: Stock
chapter.simpara: When the system is first set up, all the stock batches of ARV drugs at the pharmacy must be recorded. Tin is only done once. After this, stock arrivals must also be recorded each time they occur. Careful recording of stock allows the system to maintain accurate stock levels and produce stock reports.

sect1.title: Adding Stock
sect1.simpara: This screen displays a list of all the stock being added during the current session. For each batch, the user must perform the following steps:

listitem.simpara: Click Add Stock on the Stock Arrives at Pharmacy Screen (above). The Add Stock screen appears. It looks like this:
Use the Drug Search button to select the drug
Fill in the batch information in the lower half of the screen

sect1.simpara: When you are finished, click Save to add the stock batch. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the stock batch, press Cancel . You will now be returned to the Stock Arrives at Pharmacy screen. If you have successfully added stock, it should appear in the list on this screen. If it has not appeared, or to add another batch of this or another drug, click Add Stock and repeat the steps above.
If you have made a mistake and wish to remove a batch from the list of batches to be saved, click the batch in the stock list to select it, and click the Remove Selected Batch button.

Once you have finished adding all the stock you wish to add in this session, click Submit to save the stock. If you want to leave this screen without saving anything (all the stock you entered will be lost), click Cancel .

When you click Submit, a Stock Receipt report can generated, showing all the stock that has been entered on this day. You should check the Stock Receipt Report to be sure that the stock arrival has been recorded correctly. You can then print or save this report. See the section Printing and Saving Reports for further information about this.

chapter.title: Doctors
chapter.simpara: All the doctors who will prescribe ARV drugs to the patients being served by this pharmacy (and any remote clinics attached to it) must be added to the system.

sect1.title: Adding Doctors
sect1.simpara: Doctors are added using the Add A New Doctor screen. From the main screen, select General Admin . A new screen, the General Admin Screen, will appear. From this screen, select Add a new Doctor . The Add a New Doctor screen will appear. It looks like this:

sect1.title: Updating a Doctor's Information
sect1.simpara:
A doctor's information can be updated using the Update an Existing Doctor screen. From the main screen, select General Admin . A new screen, the General Admin Screen, will appear. From this screen, select
Update an Existing Doctor's Details
. The Update an Existing Doctor screen will appear. It looks like this:

chapter.title: Patients
chapter.simpara: The system stores detailed information on each patient receiving ARV drugs from the pharmacy and any remote clinics its supplies. This includes personal information as well as information on allergies that may influence the drugs the patient can take. Most of this information is not compulsory. The amount of information you collect from patients, and record, is left up to you. The fields marked with *, however, are compulsory.

sect1.title: Adding Patients
sect1.simpara:
Patients are added though the Add a New Patient screen. To add a patient, select Patient Admin from the main screen. The Patient Admin screen will appear. From this screen, select
Add a New Patient to the System
. This will bring up the Add a New Patient screen. It looks like this:

First, you should enter the Patient ID. This is used to uniquely identify the patient, so no two patients are allowed to have the same Patient ID. If you do try to save a patient with the same Patient ID a patient already in the system, you will be asked to change the Patient ID before you can save. The other restriction on the Patient ID relates to its l, which determines the l of the barcodes printed on labels. The maximum length of a Patient ID that contains a mixture of letters and numbers is 10 characters. For Patient IDs consisting only of numbers, the maximum length is 18 characters. Once you have chosen a Patient ID, you must enter at least the patient's first name, surname, date of birth, distribution clinic and account status. These fields, marked with *, are compulsory; the other fields are optional but recommended. Note that you cannot enter the patient's age; this is calculated from the date of birth.

The patient's next appointment date can also be set or updated from this screen. If there is no upcoming appointment for the patient, a new appointment can be added. If the patient has an upcoming appointment, the date of this appointment can be changed.

If you want to save the patient and be taken to the Add Initial Prescription screen to capture a prescription for this patient, choose
Create Initial Prescription
. If you want to save the patient, but do not want to capture a prescription for this patient at this time, choose Save .
To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the patient, press Cancel .

sect1.title: Updating a Patient's Information
sect1.simpara:
To update a patient, select Patient Admin from the main screen. The Patient Admin screen will appear. From this screen, select
Update an Existing Patient's Details
. This will bring up the Update an Existing Patient screen. It looks like this:

First, you should enter the Patient ID. You can type this in and press enter, scan the information label for a patient using a barcode scanner, or use the patient search to do this. For more information on entering Patient IDs using the patient search, please see Using the Patient Search.

Once you have entered a patient ID, the system will bring up the information it has stored about this patient. You can now edit this information. The fields marked with * are compulsory; the other fields are optional but recommended. The patient's next appointment date can also be set or updated from this screen. If there is no upcoming appointment for the patient, a new appointment can be added. If the patient has an upcoming appointment, the date of this appointment can be changed.

If you want to save the changed patient information and be taken to the Update Prescription screen to update the prescription for this patient, choose Update Prescription . If you want to save the changed patient information, but do not want to update the prescription for this patient at this time, choose Save .
To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the changed patient information, press Cancel .

sect1.title: Merging Duplicate Patients
sect1.simpara: To merge two patient records that you have determined belong to the same patient, select Patient Admin from the main screen. The Patient Admin screen will appear. From this screen, select Merge Patients . This will bring up the Merge Patients screen. It looks like this:

First, you should enter the Patient ID of the primary patient. This is the patient whose Patient ID you wish to use for the merged patient after the merge. You can type this in and press enter, scan the information label for a patient using a barcode scanner, or use the patient search to do this. For more information on entering Patient IDs using the patient search, please see Using the Patient Search.
Once you have entered a patient ID, the system will bring up the information it has stored about this patient in the Primary Patient area, as shown in the screenshot below:

You should now load up the secondary patient by entering the patient ID in the same way. The secondary patient's ID will be recorded as an old ID of the primary patient. All packages, prescriptions, appointments and episodes from the secondary patient record will be removed from this patient record, and will now belong to the merged patient.
Once both the primary and secondary patients are loaded, the merge patient details will be filled in. The screen will look like this:

You can edit the basic information about the merge patient that is shown in the text fields on this screen. If both secondary and primary patients have a valid next apointment, you should also choose one appoinment to keep. The one you do not choose will be marked as invalid, and the patient will appear on the Patients Expected On A Day report for that appointment date.

Be warned that you cannot undo a patient merge! If you are sure you want to save the patient merge, choose Save . You will be asked for your password to confirm the merge, then taken to the Update Patient screen to view and update all details for the merged patient.
To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the patient merge, press Cancel .

chapter.title: Patients' Prescriptions
chapter.simpara: The ARV prescription for a patient must be stored in the system. Information about the prescription, such as the doctor who prescribed the drugs and the clinical stage of the patient, as well as a list of all the drugs on the prescription, is stored. When a prescription changes, for example due to a renewal or the the patient displaying an adverse reation to one of the drugs, this must be recorded in a prescription update.

sect1.title: Adding Patients' Prescriptions
sect1.simpara: Before you add a prescription for a patient, you need to: Add the doctor responsible for this prescription (see Adding Doctors) Add the drugs that will be specified by this prescription (see Adding Drugs) Add the stock batches for each drug (see Adding Stock) Add the patient's distribution clinic (see Adding Distribution Clinics) if it is not already loaded Add the patient (see Adding Patients)

To add the initial prescription, select Patient Admin from the main screen. The Patient Admin screen will appear. From this screen, select
Add/Update a Patient's Prescription
. This will bring up the Patient's Prescription screen. It looks like this:

To tell the system which patient this prescription is for, enter the Patient ID. You can type this into the Patient ID text box, or you can select Patient Search to search for IDs. For more information about the Patient Search feature, please see Using the Patient Search.

Once you have entered the ID of a patient in the system, check that the patient's first name, surname and age are correct. This information is in greyed-out boxes as you cannot edit patient information here. See Updating Patient Information if you need to change information about a patient already on the system.

Select the patient's doctor from the drop-down list. Get the list to drop down by clicking the arrow on the right hand side of the box,and click an entry in the list to select it. If you wish to add a new doctor, click the button next to the drop-down list of doctors, and add the doctor here. Select the prescription duration in the same way, and also the clinical stage and weight if you would like to record this information.

The notes field is an optional area where you can record any information about the patient that you would like displayed when you are dispensing to this patient. To add notes, just click in the field and type your notes.
You can now add drugs to the prescription.
If you wish to add all drugs from a drug group, select the drug group from the drop-down list. The drugs will automatically be added to the list of drugs on this patient's prescription.
To add drugs manually, do the following for each drug you wish to add:

listitem.simpara: To add a drug, select Add Drug to this Prescription. The add a Drug screen will appear. It looks like this:
To add a drug to the prescription, you should use the drug search. For more information about the drug search, please see Using the Drug Search.
Check the information about the drug (such as its name and strength) is correct. Enter the number of units to take in each dose, and select the number of doses per day from the drop-down list.

When you are finished, click
Add to Prescription
to add the drug to the prescription. The drug will appear in the list of drugs on this prescription. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without adding the drug, press Cancel . You will be returned to the Patient's Prescription screen.

sect1.simpara: If you need to remove a drug from the drugs list, click the entry in the Drugs list to select it, and then click the Remove Selected Drug button. The system will ask you whether you wish to remove this drug - select Yes to remove the drug, or No if you do not wish to remove the drug. You can also change the order in which the drugs appear on the prescription (and hence the order in which the labels will print when the prescription is dispensed) by selecting the drug you wish to remove and clicking the up or down arrow buttons found on either side of the drugs list.

If you want to save the prescription and be taken to the Patient Packaging screen to dispense the prescription now, choose Dispense Now . If you want to save the prescription, but do not want to dispense it at this time, choose Save .
To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the prescription, press Cancel .

sect1.title: Updating Patients' Prescriptions
sect1.simpara:
To update a patient's prescription, select Patient Admin from the main screen. The Patient Admin screen will appear. From this screen, select
Add/Update a Patient's Prescription
. This will bring up the Patient's Prescription screen. It looks like this:

To tell the system which patient's prescription you wish to update, enter the Patient ID. You can type this into the Patient ID text box, or you can select Patient Search to search for IDs. For more information about the Patient Search feature, please see Using the Patient Search. Once you have entered the ID of a patient in the system, the fields on the Patient's Prescription screen should be filled with information from the patient's current prescription, as in the example below:

Select the reason you are updating the prescription from the drop-down list. Get the list to drop down by clicking the arrow on the right hand side of the box, and click an entry in the list to select it. Also check that the patient's first name, surname and age are correct. This information is in greyed-out boxes as you cannot edit patient information here. See Updating Patient Information if you need to change information about a patient already on the system.

If you wish to change the patient's doctor, select a different doctor from the drop-down list. Get the list to drop down by clicking the arrow on the right hand side of the box, and click an entry in the list to select it. If you wish to add a new doctor, click the button next to the drop-down list of doctors, and add the doctor here. Select the prescription duration in the same way, and also the clinical stage and weight if you would like to record this information.

The notes field is an optional area where you can record any information about the patient that you would like displayed when you are dispensing to this patient. To add notes, just click in the field and type your notes.
If you wish to add all drugs from a drug group, select the drug group from the drop-down list. The drugs will automatically be added to the list of drugs on this patient's prescription.
If you wish to add drugs to the prescription manually, do the following for each drug you wish to add.
To add drugs manually, do the following for each drug you wish to add:

chapter.title: Pharmacy Users
chapter.simpara: The system stores information on who at the pharmacy is allowed to log in to the system. This information is limited to a username and a password, which will be required each time the user logs in to the system.

sect1.title: Manage Pharmacy Users
sect1.simpara: The Manage Pharmacy Users screen allows the currently logged in user to

listitem.simpara: Change their password
Add a new iDART user

sect1.simpara: To access this screen, select General Admin from the main screen. A new screen, the General Admin Screen, will appear. From this screen, select Manage Pharmacy Users . The Manage Pharmacy Users screen will appear. It looks like this:

sect2.title: To add a new user:
sect2.simpara:
Select the
Add New iDART User
radio button. Enter a username for the new user in the Username field, and then enter their password in the password and confirm password fields. The text in the two fields must be identical. Note that characters in passwords appear as * symbols when entered, to prevent anyone from seeing the password being typed.
When you are finished, click Save to add the new user. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without adding a new user, press Cancel .

sect2.title: To change the password of the currently logged in user:
sect2.simpara: Select the Change Your Password radio button. Enter your old password, then enter you new password in the New Password and Confirm New Password fields. The text in the last two fields must be identical. Note that characters in passwords appear as * symbols when entered, to prevent anyone from seeing the password being typed. When you are finished, click *Save* to add the new user. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without adding a new user, press Cancel .

chapter.title: Distribution Clinics
chapter.simpara: (Please note that this section is only relevant to versions of iDART using the remote dispensing feature)

The place where a patient collects their ARV medication, whether this is located in the same building as the pharmacy or at a remote clinic, is the patient's distribution clinic. Distribution clinics are also relevant to stock, as each stock batch is assigned to a distribution clinic.

sect1.title: Adding Distribution Clinics
sect1.simpara: (Please note that this section is only relevant to versions of iDART using the remote dispensing feature)

To add a distribution clinic, log into the system and select General Admin from the main screen. A new screen, the General Admin Screen, will appear. From this screen, select Add a New Clinic . The Add a New Clinic screen will appear. It looks like this:
Fill in at least the clinic name. All other details are optional, but recommended.
When you are finished, click Save to add the new clinic. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without adding a new clinic, press Cancel .

sect1.title: Updating a Distribution Clinic's Information
sect1.simpara: (Please note that this section is only relevant to versions of iDART using the remote dispensing feature)

To update a clinic's information, select General Admin from the main screen. A new screen, the General Admin Screen , will appear. From this screen, select
Update an Existing Clinic's Details
. The Update an Existing Clinic screen will appear. It looks like this:
Enter the clinic name, or use the clinic search to find a clinic by selecting Clinic Search . This will bring up a list of the clinics currently on the system. It looks like this:

You can select a clinic by clicking an entry in the list. If you enter text in the text box below the list, the clinics whose names do not contain the text you have entered will be hidden, making it easier to find the clinic you are looking for. Once you click a clinic in the list, you will be returned to the Update an Existing Clinic screen, and information for the clinic you chose will be selected. If you do not want to select a clinic from the Clinic Search screen, select Cancel to leave the Clinic Search screen.
Once the information for an existing clinic is displayed, you can edit this information. Ensure that at least the clinic name is entered. All other details are optional, but recommended.

When you are finished, click Save to save the new information with the clinic. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without changing the information for a clinic, press Cancel .

chapter.title: Drug Groups
chapter.simpara: Drug groups serve two purposes:

listitem.simpara: When adding drugs to a new prescription for a patient, you can select a drug group and all the drugs in the drug group will be added to the prescription, speeding the prescription capture process.

Each drug group is associated with a regimen. This means that iDART can count how many patients are on each regimen by comparing the Â drugs on the patients' prescriptions with the drugs in the drug group. For this reason, it's important that the drug groups are captured accurately.

chapter.simpara: Examples of drug groups that would be associated with regimen 1A could be

listitem.simpara: Stavudine 30mg BID, Lamivudine 150mg BID, Efavirenz 600mg QD
Stavudine 40mg BID, Lamivudine 150mg BID, Efavirenz 600mg QD

sect1.title: Add Drug Groups
sect1.simpara: To add a new drug group, select General Admin from the main screen. The General Admin screen will appear. From this screen, select Add a New Drug Group . This will bring up the Drug Groups screen. It looks like this:

Enter a name for the new drug group. Then, select the regimen that this drug group comprises. Please be careful when setting a regimen - a drug group only belongs to a regimen when it contains all the drugs required for that regimen. Once you have selected the drug group, the fields on the Drug Groups screen should be filled with the Drug Group's current information, as in the example below:
To add drugs to the drug group, do the following for each drug you wish to add:

listitem.simpara: To add a drug, select Add Drug to this Prescription. The add a Drug screen will appear. It looks like this:
To add a drug to the prescription, you should use the drug search. For more information about the drug search, please see Using the Drug Search.
Check the information about the drug (such as its name and strength) is correct. Enter the number of units to take in each dose, and select the number of doses per day from the drop-down list.

When you are finished, click Add to Group to add the drug to the drug group. The drug will appear in the list of drugs in the drug group. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without adding the drug, press Cancel . You will be returned to the Drug Groups screen

sect1.simpara: If you need to remove a drug from the Drugs list, click the entry in the Drugs list. The system will ask you whether you wish to remove this drug - select Yes to remove the drug, or No if you do not wish to remove the drug.
If you want to save the drug group, choose Save .
To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the drug group, press Cancel .

sect1.title: Updating Drug Groups
sect1.simpara:
To update an existing drug group, select General Admin from the main screen. The General Admin screen will appear. From this screen, select
Update an Existing Group's Details
. This will bring up the Drug Groups screen. It looks like this:
To select the drug group you wish to update, click the Drug Group Search button. Select the drug group, then click Ok.
Once you have selected the drug group, the fields on the Drug Groups screen should be filled with the Drug Group's current information.

If you need to change the regimen that the drugs in this drug group comprise, you can do so by selecting a different regimen. Please be careful when setting a regimen - a drug group only belongs to a regimen when it contains all the drugs required for that regimen.

If you wish to add drugs to the drug group, do the following for each drug you wish to add: * To add a drug, select Add Drug to this Prescription. The add a Drug screen will appear. It looks like this:

listitem.simpara: To add a drug to the prescription, you should use the drug search. For more information about the drug search, please see Using the Drug Search.
Check the information about the drug (such as its name and strength) is correct. Enter the number of units to take in each dose, and select the number of doses per day from the drop-down list.

When you are finished, click Add to Group to add the drug to the drug group. The drug will appear in the list of drugs in the drug group. To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without adding the drug, press Cancel . You will be returned to the Drug Groups screen

sect1.simpara: If you need to remove a drug from the Drugs list, click the entry in the Drugs list. The system will ask you whether you wish to remove this drug - select Yes to remove the drug, or No if you do not wish to remove the drug.
If you want to save the drug group, choose Save .
To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without saving the drug group, press Cancel .

chapter.title: Packaging and Dispensing
chapter.simpara: This section describes the creation of ARV packages for patients, and how to dispense the package to the patient either directly, by pre-packing for patients at this pharmacy, or by pre-packing for patients at a remote clinic.

sect1.title: Creating Patient ARV Packages
sect1.simpara:
This section describes how to create monthly ARV packages for patients according to their prescriptions. Dispensing the package to the patient, either directly from the pharmacy or via a distribution clinic, is covered in the two subsequent sections. From the main screen, select
Stock & Dispensing
. This will open the Stock Control screen - select
Make Up Drug Packages For Patients
. This will open the Make Up ARV Packages for Patients screen, which is shown below:
First, check that the correct dispensing mode is selected. You can choose one of:

listitem.simpara:
I am creating packages for later pickup
if the drugs will be picked up at another time, or at a distribution clinic. The date the package was packed will be recorded, but not the date it left the pharmacy - this will be recorded when the package leaves the pharmacy to a patient or to a distribution clinic. See Dispensing from a Remote Clinic. You will not need to record the adherence information on this screen if you are doing this type of dispensing.

I am dispensing directly to patients
if the patient will take the package now, and today's date should be recorded as the date the package was packed, left the pharmacy and was picked up by the patient. The system will not record any further tracking information about this package as it will be considered dispensed to the patient. You will be able to record adherence information for the patient on this screen if you are doing this kind of dispensing.

sect1.simpara: Both the above options will cause labels for all the drugs in the packages to be printed. If you choose Create Package for Later, a package cover label will also be printed.

Select a distribution clinic from the drop-down list. This will bring up a list of all the patients for whom ARV packages should be made up. The list includes all patients at the selected clinic who have current prescriptions.

Select a patient from the list to start making up a package for that patient. If you are looking for a specific patient, try using the search bar (the text box directly below the patient list). Typing a character or a few characters in this box will hide the Patient IDs in the list that do not contain the character(s) you have typed.

Clicking a Patient ID in the list of waiting patients will cause information about the patient to come up in the Patient Information area, and information about the patient's current prescription to come up in the Prescription Information area. The drugs that a package for this patient should contain will be shown in red in the drugs table. At this point, also be aware of notes displayed for the patient. If the patient is a child, the system will warn you by placing a small icon showing a child next to the age field. This icon looks like this:
You need to dispense at least one of the drugs in the list, but you do not have to dispense them all. To dispense drugs:

listitem.simpara: You need to select how many months' or weeks' supply this package represents from the drop-down list. This will allow the system to pre-calculate the number of pills to dispense. By default, these will come from the batch that will expire soonest.

When the system records a patient as having received a package, the patient's next appointment date is set according to how many months or weeks supply of ARV drugs the package contains. If you are dispensing directly to patients, the next appointment date will therefore be recorded from this screen. In this case, you can set the next appointment date in the Patient Information section. If you are creating packages for later pickup, the next appointment date will be set automatically when the package is scanned out as it is collected by the patient.

The table of
Drugs To Dispense in This Package
will automatically be populated, as will the
Pill Count â€“ Last Package
table. You need to:

Fill in accumulated units the patient returns with. This information will be used to calculate the patient's adherence. To fill in a value, click the cell in the Accum column of the
Pill Count â€“ Last Package
table, and type the value. The adherence percentage will be caulculated immediately

Check the total units in hand for each drug, which will appear in the In Hand column of the
Drugs To Dispense in This Package
table. This can have two values, which you can choose by clicking in the column and selecting the value from the dropdown list. You can either record that the patient has left with the number of units you dispensed as well as the number of units accumulated (e.g. 1 pack of 60 pills + 2 pills accumulated), or that you did not give the accumulated units back to the patient for whatever reason, and that they left with just the quantity you dispensed (e.g. 1 pack of 60 pills).

If desired, change the number of labels to print by clicking the cell in the labels column, and changing the value to the desired number of labels. You can then edit the batch to dispense from, as well as the quantity to dispense, by clicking the row containing the drug information. This will bring up the screen below:

You can change the quantity (in pills) to dispense. To do this, click the row of the batch you wish to dispense from, under the column Qty to Dispense, and type in the number of pills. The drugs are ordered by expiry date, with the batch that will expire soonest listed first. You can also select how many drug labels you wish to print, from the drop-down list in the Labels to Print column.To maintain correct stock levels, it's important that the containers you put in to the package do in fact come from the batch you have selected.

Select
Add Drug to Package
to save the information you have entered. Select Cancel if you do not wish to add this drug to the package at this time.

sect1.simpara: Once you have specified quantities for each drug you wish to add, you should specify whether you want the dosage quantities on the label to be left blank (eg. for paediatric patients where you want to fill in this information by hand) and also whether a script summary label should be printed. Do this by selecting your choices (Yes or No) below the drugs table.

To create the drug package and print the relevant labels, select Create Package . If you do not want to create a package at this time, you can choose Close to close the Make Up ARV Packages for Patients screen. If you make a mistake with a package and want to redo it, select Redo an ARV Package . For more information about this, please see Stock, Prescription and Package Deletions in this section.

sect1.title: Pre-packaging for patients at this Pharmacy
sect1.simpara: If you are pre-packaging for patients who collect their drugs at the pharmacy, the system tracks packages by recording two dates:

listitem.simpara: The date the package was packed
The date the package was picked up by the patient.

sect1.simpara: Packages that have been pre-packed must be scanned using a barcode scanner as they leave to record the second date.

To record a package leaving the pharmacy to be given to a patient, select
Stock & Dispensing
from the main screen. From the Stock Control screen, select
Scan Out Packages To Patients
. This will cause the Distribute ARV Packages screen below to open.

First, select a clinic from the drop-down list. This will cause the Package IDs of all the packages waiting to leave for this clinic to appear in the list on the left. Use a barcode scanner to scan the package IDs of the packages that will leave the pharmacy now. Note that in the event of problems with scanning, you can type the Package IDs in by hand.

When you have finished scanning, you can choose
View Report of Packages Dispensed
to see a report of the packages that have left the pharmacy today. You can print or save the report - please see Printing and Saving Reports for further information on this. If you wish to leave this screen without seeing a report, you can choose Close .

sect1.title: Pre-packaging for patients at Remote Clinics
sect1.simpara: (Please note that this section is only relevant to versions of iDART using the remote dispensing feature)
If you are pre-packaging for patients who collect their drugs at remote clinics, the system tracks packages by recording four dates:

listitem.simpara: The date the package was packed
The date the package left the pharmacy
The date the package arrived at the remote clinic
The date the package was picked up by the patient.

sect1.simpara: Packages that have been pre-packed must be scanned using a barcode scanner as they leave to record the second date. The third and fourth dates are recorded when the package is scanned at the clinic using the iDART clinic application.

To record a package leaving the pharmacy, select
Stock & Dispensing
from the main screen. From the Stock Control screen, select
Scan Out Packages To Remote Clinic
. This will cause the Distribute ARV Packages screen below to open.

First, select a clinic from the drop-down list. This will cause the Package IDs of all the packages waiting to leave for this clinic to appear in the list on the left. Use a barcode scanner to scan the package IDs of the packages that will leave the pharmacy now. Note that in the event of problems with scanning, you can type the Package IDs in by hand.

When you have finished scanning, you can choose
View Report of Packages Dispensed
to see a report of the packages that have left the pharmacy today. You can print or save the report - please see Printing and Saving Reports for further information on this. If you wish to leave this screen without seeing a report, you can choose Close .

sect1.title: Stock, Prescription and Package Deletions
sect1.simpara: You can perform 4 types of deletions in iDART. These are:

listitem.simpara:
Package Deletions
: Delete the most recent package for a patient, for example when the patient fails to collect their drug package.

Single Package Item Deletions
: Delete an item in the most recent package for a patient.

Prescription Deletions
: Delete a patient's incorrectly captured prescription, if this prescription has not been dispensed

Stock Batch Deletions
: Delete an incorrectly captured stock batch, if no drugs have been dispensed from this batch

sect1.simpara:
All the above deletions require the currently logged in user to provide their password before the deletion occurs. A log of the deletion is also created, and a report showing all logged deletions for a time period can be viewed by selecting
Transaction Log Report
from the Reports screen.

sect2.title: To perform a package deletion:
sect2.simpara:
Select the
Return Uncollected Packages
radio button. Enter a Patient ID, or use the patient search to select the patient whose package you want to remove. The most recent package for this patient, if any, will be shown, as well as the drugs the package contains. To remove the package, select
Remove this Package
. If you do not wish to remove a package at this time, select Cancel .

sect2.title: To perform a single package item deletion:
sect2.simpara:
Select the
Red Single Item in Package
radio button. Enter a Patient ID, or use the patient search to select the patient whose package item you want to remove. The most recent package for this patient, if any, will be shown, as well as the drugs the package contains. To remove an accumulated or dispensed drug, select the row containing that drug's information and click Remove this Drug . If you do not wish to remove a package item at this time, select Cancel .

sect2.title: To perform a prescription deletion:
sect2.simpara:
Select the
Delete Incorrect Prescription
radio button. Enter a Patient ID, or use the patient search to select the patient whose prescription you want to remove. Any prescription for this patient that can be removed (i.e. has not yet been dispensed) will be shown, as well as the drugs on the prescription. To remove the prescription, select
Remove this Prescription
. If you do not wish to remove a prescription at this time, select Cancel .
Please note that you cannot remove just one drug in a prescription - the entire prescription must be removed and redone.

sect2.title: To perform a stock batch deletion:
sect2.simpara:
Select the
Delete Incorrect Stock Batch
radio button. Use the Drug Search button to select the drug for which you wish to remove a batch. Any batches for this drug that can be removed (i.e. has not yet been dispensed) will be shown, To remove a batch, click the batch in the list and select
Remove Selected Batch
. If you do not wish to remove a stock batch at this time, select Cancel .

sect1.title: Destroying Unusable Stock
sect1.simpara: When stock expires or is thrown away for any other reason, this must be recorded in iDART to ensure that stock levels remain correct.

First, select the drug for which you are destroying stock using the Drug Search button (for more information on this, see Using the Drug Search). Any stock batches that are recorded as having stock remaining will now be displayed in the Stock Information table, ordered with the batch that will expire soonest at the top.

Enter a reason for disposal, which will be displayed in the transaction log. Then, click once in the row displaying information about the batch from which you wish to destroy stock, under the column Packs To Destroy or Loose Pills To Destroy . You should now be able to type in the number of packs and / or loose pills you want to destroy. Note that the number of loose pills (or ml, in the case of liquids) destroyed must always be less than the number of pills (or ml) in a pack. If you wanted to destroy 90 pills of a drug with a packsize of 60, for example, you should record this as 1 pack and 30 loose pills destroyed.

When you have finished, click Save to record the stock destruction. Stock destructions require the currently logged in user to provide their password before the destructions occurs. A log of the destructions is also created, and a report showing all logged transactions for a time period can be viewed by selecting
Transaction Log Report
from the Reports screen.
To clear the screen and start over without saving anything, click Clear . To leave the screen without saving anything, click Cancel .

chapter.title: Printing Labels
chapter.simpara: This section describes how to print a patient information label or an emergency label for a package, a drug in a package or a patient. Generally, printing of package and drug labels takes place during the creation of packages and is not controlled by the user; however this section also includes some hints for troubleshooting common problems with these automatically generated package and drug labels.

sect1.title: Printing a Custom Label
sect1.simpara: A custom label is a label on which certain information (such as the Patient ID, or the dosage of a drug) is typed manually by the user, and not generated automatically by the system. This type of label is not associated with any other transaction in the system, such as the preparation of a package - this function exists only to allow the user to create custom labels in special circumstances. It does not talk to the database except to retreive the pharmacy details.

Printing of emergency package cover, drug or patient labels takes place from the Print an Emergency Label screen. From the main screen, select Stock Control . This will bring up the Stock Control screen - from this screen, select
Make up ARV Packages for Patients
. This will bring up the Make up ARV Packages for Patients screen. From this screen, select Create Emergency Label. The Create Emergency Label screen looks like this:

First, select the kind of label you want to print. The editable areas are the areas of the label with a gray background. Clicking in one of these areas allows you to edit the text in this area. Note that for the package label, the Package ID will be replaced by the barcode representing it, and also printed in plain text below the barcode.

Once you have a label that contains all the correct information, you can select the number of labels you wish to print for this patient from the drop-down box. Then, select Print to print the label(s). You will be prompted to select a printer; do this and press Print .
To clear all the text fields, press Clear . To leave the screen without printing any labels, press Cancel .

sect1.title: Troubleshooting Label Printing
sect1.simpara: Please note that the system is designed to use labels of size 3" by 2", and the Zebra range of label printers. These instructions apply to this printer, although they may still be useful if you have a different label printer. Please also note that these instructions are for computers running Microsoft Windows XP.
If you need to be talked through these procedures, or if this does not solve your problem, please call the Cell-Life iDART help desk (see How to Get Help).

sect2.title: Setting your label printer as the default printer:
sect2.simpara: Zebra printers seem to work better when set as the default printer. This is usually the first thing to try when you experience printing problems. To set your label printer as the default printer, do the following:

Go to Start Programs, then Control Panel. This will bring up the Windows control panel. Click on Printers and Other Hardware, then View Installed Printers And Faxes. This should show all your installed printers. Use the right mouse button to click on the printer that prints your labels. This should bring up a menu â€“ select Set as Default to set this printer as your default printer.

sect2.title: Setting the label size for your label printer:
sect2.simpara: If your labels are not printing correctly, you may need to reset the paper size on your printer. To do this, go to Start Programs, then Control Panel. This will bring up the Windows control panel. Click on Printers and Other Hardware, then View Installed Printers And Faxes. This should show all your installed printers. Use the right mouse button to click on the printer that prints your labels. This should bring up a menu - select Properties, one of the last items on this menu. You should see the printer properties screen. Select Printing Preferences. The screen you see should look something like this:
Click the + sign next to Paper/Output. This will show you the paper settings. Click on the paper size (blue, underlined text) to change this. Set the paper size to 2" x 3".

chapter.title: Generating Reports
chapter.simpara: This section explains how to produce reports based on the data in the database. The reports can then be saved or printed, for your own records.

sect1.title: Patient History Report
sect1.simpara: The Patient History Report shows all previous prescriptions for a patient, as well as information about the prescription. Prescriptions are ordered by date.

To see a Patient History Report, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Patient History Report
. The screen below will open:

Select the patient's distribution point from the drop-down list. Then, select the patient by Patient ID from the list of patients at that clinic. If you want to shorten the list, hiding those Patient IDs that do not contain a certain series of characters, type the characters the Patient ID must contain in the text box below the list of Patient IDs. If you are unclear about how this works, please see Using the Patient Search, which describes a similar method of finding the correct Patient ID.
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Pepfar Report
sect1.simpara: This report shows similar indicators to those in the Monthly Clinic Indicator report, but is intended specifically for reporting to PEPFAR.
To see a Pepfar Report, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select Pepfar Report . The Pepfar Report screen will open. It looks like this:
You should select:

listitem.simpara: The start and end date for the report, by clicking a date on each calendar.
The cutoff age for paediatric patients
The cutoff age for the young paediatric patients subset

sect1.simpara: Then, select View Report to see the Pepfar Report for the period you have specified. Select Cancel to return to the Reports Screen.
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Patient Defaulters
sect1.simpara: A Patient Defaulters Report is a report of all patients who have not picked up their packages within a user-specified number of days from their expected appointment date.

To see a Patient Defaulters Report report, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Patient Defaulters Report
.
The next screen to open will be the Patient Defaulters screen. It looks like this:

From this screen, you will need to select the distribution point for which you wish to generate a patient defaulters report. You can also edit the minimum number of days a patient must be to be considered a defaulter, and the maximum number of days late a patient should be to be shown on this report. Then, select View Report to see a Patient Defaulters report for the distribution point you have specified (or Cancel to return to the Reports Screen).
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Daily Dispensing Totals Report
sect1.simpara: A Daily Dispensing Totals Report shows the number of patients seen and the number of ARV drugs (in containers, rounded up) dispensed each day for a month.

To see a Daily Dispensing Totals Report, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Daily Dispensing Totals
.
The next screen to open will be the Daily Dispensing Totals screen. It looks like this:

From this screen, you will need to select the distribution point for which you wish to generate daily dispensing totals, as well as the month and year. Then, select View Report to see a Daily Dispensing Totals report for the distribution point, month and year you have specified (or Cancel to return to the Reports Screen).
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Monthly Stock Receipts
sect1.simpara: A Monthly Stock Receipt report is a list of all the stock that has arrived at the pharmacy during a certain month.

To see a Monthly Stock Receipt, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Monthly Stock Receipts
.
The next screen to open will be the Monthly Stock Receipts screen. It looks like this:

From this screen, you will need to select the month for which you wish to generate the report. Do this by selecting the month and year from the drop-down lists. Then, select View Report to see a Monthly Stock Receipt report for the period you have specified (or Close to return to the Reports Screen).
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Monthly Clinic Indicator Report
sect1.simpara: The Monthly Clinic Indicator Report shows statistics for each clinic, for a certain month. This is divided into paediatric and adult patient statistics. The report also contains regimen information, which relies on correctly defined Drug Groups (see Drug Groups)

To see a Monthly Clinic Indicator Report , select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Monthly Clinic Indicator Report
. The Monthly Clinic Indicator Report screen will open. It looks like this:
You should select a distribution point from the drop-down list, and also set values for the parameters:

listitem.simpara: Minimum Days Late, which is the shortest length of time that must elapse after a patient was expected to collect a package, for them to be considered a defaulter.
Cutoff Age For Paediatric Patients

sect1.simpara: Then, select View Report to see a Monthly Clinic Indicator Report for the distribution point and parameters you have specified (or Cancel to return to the Reports Screen).
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Patients Expected On A Day
sect1.simpara: This report shows a list of patients expected on a given day. The list is generated by comparing the next appointment date for each patient with the date chosen on the Patients Expected On A Day screen.

To see a list of patients expected on a day, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Patients Expected On A Day
. The Patients Expected On A Day screen will open. It looks like this:

From this screen, you will need to select a distribution point and also a date for the report. Select the distribution point from the drop-down list. To specify a date range, select the month and year from the drop-down lists, and clicking a date on each calender. Then, select View Report to see a Patients Expected On A Day list for the date and distribution point you have specified.
Select Cancel to return to the Reports Screen, or Clear to remain at this screen but clear the information (distribution point and date range) you have entered.
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: ARV Drug Usage Report
sect1.simpara: The ARV Drug Usage report shows, for a user-specified set of drugs, how many units of each drug were dispensed per day. This is displayed for a user-specified date range.

To see an ARV Drug Usage report, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select ARV Drug Usage Report . The ARV Drug Usage report screen will open. It looks like this:

From this screen, you will need to select the drugs to include (up to a maximum of 11), and also a date range for the report. To select the drugs, click the check boxes in the Drugs list. To specify a date range, click a date on each calender. Then, select View Report to see an ARV Drug Usage report for the period you have specified. Select Cancel to return to the Reports Screen, or Clear to remain at this screen but clear the information (drugs and date range) you have entered.
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Monthly Report of Receipts and Issues of ARV Drugs
sect1.simpara: This report shows a record of stock levels, receipts and issues for a certain month at a certain clinic.

To see a Monthly Report of Receipts and Issues of ARV Drugs, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Monthly Report of Receipts and Issuse of ARV Drugs
. The Monthly Stock Overview screen will open. It looks like this:

You should select the distribution point, month and year from the drop-down lists. Then, select View Report to see a Monthly Report of Receipts and Issuse of ARV Drugs for the month and distribution point you have specified. Select Cancel to return to the Reports Screen, or Clear to remain at this screen but clear the information ( distribution point and month) you have entered.
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.title: Transaction Log Report
sect1.simpara: The Transaction Log Report shows all logged transactions (deletions and stock destructions). This is displayed for a user-specified date range.

To see an Transaction Log Report, select Reports from the main screen. This will open the Reports screen. From the Reports screen, select
Transaction Log Report
. The Transaction Log Report report screen will open. It looks like this:

From this screen, you will need to select a date range for the report. To specify a date range, click a date on each calender. Then, select View Report to see a Transaction Log Report for the period you have specified. Select Cancel to return to the Reports Screen.
The report will open in a Report Viewer. You can now print or save the report. For information about this, please see Printing and Saving Reports.

sect1.simpara: Reports will open in a window like the one below:

sect2.title: To print the report:
sect2.simpara: Click on the printer button in the icon bar at the top of the viewer. The button is second from the left. This will bring up a screen that will let you choose a printer and associated settings. It looks like this:

sect2.title: To save the report:
sect2.simpara: Click on the save button in the icon bar at the top of the viewer. The button is the first from the left hand side. This will bring up the following screen:

You can select the file format in which the report should be saved from the drop-down list (shown dropped down in the image). The recommended format is PDF, which can be read by Adobe Acrobat and a number of free viewers, such as xpdf, but cannot be modified. Choose a file format, and give the file a name. Also navigate to the place you want to save the file, and then press Save .

chapter.title: Frequently Asked Questions
chapter.simpara: This section offers answers to some frequently asked questions regarding the day-to-day use of the system. If you have a problem that you cannot find a solution to in the rest of the manual, you may be able to solve it by refering to this section. However, if you are unsuccessful, please call the Cell-Life iDART Helpdesk, where one of the system's developers will assist you.

sect1.title: Using the Patient Search
sect1.simpara: Pressing Patient Search will bring up a list of the IDs and names of all the patients in the system. If you enter a chapter of a Patient ID or name, the system will shorten the list by hiding all those patients whose names and IDs do not contain the characters you have entered. You can also scroll through the list of patients using the arrows on the right hand side. For example, if the system has patients ABC112, ABC122 and ABC123, entering ABC will not hide any of the patient IDs, but entering ABC11 will hide the second and third IDs as only the first (ABC112) can match ABC11. Note that the search is not case sensitive, ie. AB, ab and Ab are the same.
This screenshot shows the Patient Search screen displaying all the patients in the system:
This screenshot shows the Patient Search screen displaying only patients with IDs or names containing ab:

Note that most patient search screens will only allow you to search patients whose account status is active . For example, you can't add a prescription for an inactive patient, so there will not be inactive patients in the search on the Add/Update Prescription screen. The exception is the Update Patient screen, where you can search through all patients, active or inactive

When you have found the patient you are looking for, click on the ID in the list. This will close the Patient Search screen and bring up the relevant information about the patient whose ID you selected. Clicking Cancel from the Patient Search screen will close the screen but not bring up information about any patients.

sect1.title: Using the Drug Search
sect1.simpara: Pressing Drug Search will bring up a list of the drugs in the system, and their pack sizes. If you enter a chapter of a drug name, the system will shorten the list by hiding all those drugs whose names do not contain the characters you have entered. You can also scroll through the list of drugs using the arrows on the right hand side. Note that the search is not case sensitive, ie. AB, ab and Ab are the same.
